</details>

</details>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|1384|1|erw|

Current commit [317d02b389](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/317d02b389427d86be676573495a59e126afa26f)
Reference commit [a42d40c055](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/a42d40c0557e574eef833c60cb0a35edef417803)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21362~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
I went through most of the overall strategy and docstrings, but I yet have to have a closer look at the proofs, which I'll hopefully find time to do before the end of the week.
I went through most of the overall strategy and docstrings, but I yet have to have a closer look at the proofs, which I'll hopefully find time to do before the end of the week.

Would it be worthy to try to track degree and number of open sets separately?
(I'd say yes: in some parts of AG, it's useful to know that some varieties are defined by equations of degree 2.)

Do you mean "number of polynomials" rather than "number of open sets"? We're tracking the former, not the latter.

Given the shape of the bound (a tower of size depending on both the degree and number of polynomials used to describe the original variety), I doubt it is possible to track both variables independently.

Maybe what Antoine is asking, is to have separate bounds on the degree and the number of polynomials, not necessarily independent of each other? In this case, it seems that this is what actually happens in `chevalley_mvPolynomial_mvPolynomial`, but this doc string does suggest something else, namely that there is only one `M` bounding both the number of polynomials and degrees. Could you clarify this in this docstring?
What property is there for `PrimeSpectrum` that makes this true and not for more general topological spaces?

It's the presence of a basis consisting of compact sets whose pairwise intersections are compact too. See https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/0069

Note that the general case is already proved: it's `IsTopologicalBasis.isRetrocompact_iff_isCompact` and we're using it here
Actually, it's equivalent to there being a basis of compact sets and the space being quasi-separated. See #21325.
This name does not follow the naming convention, right? Maybe `MvPolynomial.exists_constructibleSetData_image_eq`? Similarly above.
Also, could you please make sure that the `n` and `m` subscripts in the docstring correspond to LHS and RHS in the statement?
This does not exist (yet), right?

This sentence seems to suggest that constructible sets in a prime spectrum are always open, which is not the case. Also, what do you mean by "polynomial" here? `R` is here still just an arbitrary ring, right?

```suggestion
/-- The measure that will decrease during the induction in the `C : R â†’ R[X]` case of
Chevalley's theorem with complexity bound. -/
```

I am also confused by "open set" here. Should it be closed set? Or "if its complement can be written ..."?
Maybe it makes sense to stick to the presentation you used in [PrimeSpectrum.ConstructibleSetData](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Spectrum/Prime/ConstructibleSet.html#PrimeSpectrum.ConstructibleSetData)? Right now, I find it hard to match your high level description here up with the docstring of `chevalley_mvPolynomial_mvPolynomial`.
What do you think of defining projections `ConstructibleSetData.f`, `ConstructibleSetData.n` and `ConstructibleSetData.g` to make these `x.2.1` less hard to parse?
This is not `p.coeffs`, because it contains `0`. Is there a reason why you want to have `0` in there?

```suggestion
/-- The bound on the degree of the polynomials used to describe the constructible set appearing in the
case of `C : R â†’ R[X]` of Chevalley's theorem with complexity bound. -/
```

```suggestion
describe the constructible set appearing in the case of `C : R â†’ R[X]` of Chevalley's theorem with
complexity bound. -/
```

```suggestion
  âˆ€ f : R[X], âˆƒ T : ConstructibleSetData R,
    comap Polynomial.C '' (zeroLocus (Set.range e.val) \ zeroLocus {f}) = T.toSet âˆ§
    âˆ€ C âˆˆ T, C.2.1 â‰¤ e.degBound âˆ§ âˆ€ i, C.2.2 i âˆˆ e.coeffSubmodule Râ‚€ ^ e.powBound
```
I don't think this is used? You seem to write `e.val i` everywhere instead.
Why is this `private`? This might possibly be independently useful? (Probably without the type synonym `InductionObj` though).

```suggestion
/-- Part 4 of the induction structure applied to `Statement Râ‚€ R n`. See the docstring of `induction_structure`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- The bound on the degree of the polynomials used to describe the constructible set appearing in the
```
